context.text: Well, I think this does go back to Justice Alito's question, because the person can say -- the defendant here could have said, I really don't care whether the bank ends up paying Target.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I don't know whether the bank will end up paying Target.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I don't know how these things work and how often the bank honors it and how often the bank doesn't honor it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: Yes, that's exactly right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And -- and you've been slipping back into the hypotheticals where the bank is going to bear the loss.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But your position also covers instances where the bank does not bear any loss, the fraudulent contractor that -- Justice Kagan's hypothetical about the phony painting, the bank is not going to give that money back.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: And -- and for good reason, for multiple reasons.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: One, this is prohibiting the scheme, not a good scheme, not a completed scheme, not an effective scheme and--

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: --Well, this -- this Court has long recognized that the word ‶ obtain ″ not only means that you obtain it for yourself, but you can obtain something by directing the transfer of -- of property to someone else.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: And that's exactly what a check does.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: You are directing the--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Yang, before you finish, Mr. Russell pointed out -- and I think Justice Sotomayor -- that there is Section 513.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It deals with -- expressly with altered checks, but the penalty is much, much less.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is everything that is covered by 513 covered by 1344, too?

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: In those contexts, you might have someone who is scheming to obtain bank property by directing their fraud to a third party to whom the bank has entrusted their assets.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: No, but in a case like this, wouldn't the difficulties of proof be the same?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The person -- whether you charge somebody with trying to defraud the bank or with trying to obtain property owned by or in the custody of the bank.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: If Justice Alito is right as to the one, that all these questions about the relationship between a bank and a retailer are going to come in, isn't he also right as to the other?

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: I'm not quite -- I don't think that's quite right.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: And the reason is that whenever you have to show an additional intent requirement, it ups the ante.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: --Grave risk of harm.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Grave risk of harm to the child.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: --or if the court finds that it would be an intolerable situation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But, again, as Justice Ginsburg questions, it seems to me indicates, there are two different axes here.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: One is the best interest of the child and the other is an adequate deterrent so that parents don't abduct.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But those axes don't cross very often, if at all.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: Absent equitable tolling, the courts -- the question on which -- the question before the court is: Is this child settled?

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: And the factors the court's looked at, the courts have looked at it, and it really -- they're -- you know, settlement is not defined in the Convention and Congress has left it to courts to decide.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: And courts look at--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, which of the articles -- which of the provisions in Article 13 would -- would prevent the return in the hypothetical that Justice Alito just gave you?

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: --Courts have looked at -- and I'll say it -- in the decades--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, what -- what does Article 13 allow the court to consider?

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: It's really B.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: B:

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: "There is grave risk that his or her return would expose the child to physical or psychological harm. "

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, we have no reason to believe that -- that your client would -- would harm the child or -- or that the parent in Justice Alito's hypothetical would harm the child.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: "Or otherwise place the child in an intolerable situation. "

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't see how any of those things would -- would come to the assistance of the child in -- in Justice Alito's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: "There is grave risk that his or her return would expose the child to physical or psychological harm. "

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, we have no reason to believe that -- that your client would -- would harm the child or -- or that the parent in Justice Alito's hypothetical would harm the child.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: "Or otherwise place the child in an intolerable situation. "

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't see how any of those things would -- would come to the assistance of the child in -- in Justice Alito's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: If I may explain by way of illustration in some of the cases what courts have looked at.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: And let me give -- Blondin is another example cited in our brief, cited by the Solicitor General, a Second Circuit, the well-known Second Circuit case.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Physical or psychological harm.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: And there are cases, Mendez v. Lynch and others.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It might be now and then, but in the routine case that Justice Alito just gave you I don't see how there's any -- any reason at all not to get the child back from wherever he's been for 10 years.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: If I may answer in two ways in the example Justice Alito gave.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: With a 10-year-old child, it's -- it's very likely that the court would hear from that child.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: Here was the wrong outcome because they applied equitable tolling as they have been doing for nearly two decades.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: Courts can do this.

context.speaker: Shawn P.  Regan
context.text: But the question, as it is in Cannon, can't be as simple as well, are you -- are you doing fine here in the United States?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Regan, Justice Breyer pointed out that all other countries seem to disagree with you.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That's obviously a concern of ours when we interpret a treaty, that all other countries interpret it in a -- in a single way.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Do you contest that?

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: No, Your Honor, because if the parent is concealing the child -- for example, if the parent is moving from place to place to evade detection or changing the child's name or not enrolling the child in school to avoid detection--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --My gosh, all it takes it moving to Peoria.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I mean, I don't mean to denigrate Peoria, but all it takes is moving to a place that has no connection to--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Sotomayor is from New York.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --Yes, obviously.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Why should those two children be treated differently?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Why should one have the benefit of settled now and the other not have it?

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: Your Honor, I think--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What sense does it make when, as Justice Alito indicated, part of the central purposes of the Convention is to avoid the kidnapping of children?

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: --Your Honor, absolutely, that is one of the objectives of the Convention, and it exists because that was presumed to be contrary to the interest of children.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: And I don't dispute that.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: But they also recognized that at some point in time it wasn't going to be just about children at large.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: It was going to be about--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So why isn't Article 13 enough protection?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It has to do with -- and unlike Justice Scalia, I don't think it's psychological or physical harm necessarily by the parent, but by the situation.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The return.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: They wanted to be able to take into account the situation of the child after this one year.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: And why one year and not one year including the hearing, I think it was a balance.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: The drafters were concerned both that it was going to be too long and that it was going to be too short.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Ms. Moskowitz, going back to Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Could you tell me how you think this works?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You said, in response to Justice Alito, that sometimes concealment can be a factor in determining whether a child is settled.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: The drafters were concerned both that it was going to be too long and that it was going to be too short.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Ms. Moskowitz, going back to Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Could you tell me how you think this works?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You said, in response to Justice Alito, that sometimes concealment can be a factor in determining whether a child is settled.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And I presume you mean if somebody conceals the child by moving the child from place to place, the child would not be settled.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Is it also a factor in determining whether a settled child should nonetheless be returned?

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: And I think--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Or under Article 18.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think your answer to Justice Kagan's question has to be no, or else I don't understand what we're doing here.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: No, Your Honor, because a full-blown merits, best-interest-of-the-child analysis under the -- the custody-type family court proceeding that is envisioned to follow a return petition under the Convention will take all of those facts into account.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: No, but prior to that.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: Prior to.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: If you could go back to -- do you agree with Justice Scalia, that really, at that point, there's nothing to do?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Once the determination has been made that the child is settled, there is no remaining discretion that the judge has?

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: Your Honor, I think there is some discretion under Article 12 to return the settled child, but it cannot be under a set of facts that were completely within the minds of the drafters when they chose the one-year period.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Oh, it is not.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, then, gee, we don't have a lot to argue about.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Well, if that's the case, if you're reading it that way -- I mean, I was reading it Justice Scalia's way, too.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Of course.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The first clause says shall and the second clause says shall not.

context.speaker: Lauren A. Moskowitz
context.text: Thank you.

context.text: Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Ann O'Connell Adams
context.text: --It's our position that under Article 12 there is discretion to return a settled child, and that that comes from Article 12 itself.

context.text: They have access to all sorts of federal law enforcement databases to try to determine if the child has come here.

context.speaker: Ann O'Connell Adams
context.text: They have--

context.text: How -- how would that be aid be invoked?

context.text: Take Justice Scalia's example.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The parent left behind in Mexico, no resources of her own or his own.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: How would the State Department get into the act?

context.speaker: Ann O'Connell Adams
context.text: That -- that an abducted child should be returned.

context.speaker: Ann O'Connell Adams

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Scalia?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You know, I have one more question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: At the end of the day, now that I understand the government's position, I don't see any difference between your position and -- and the position of -- of the Petitioner here except that he wants to call it equitable tolling, and you want to say we can take concealment into account under Section 12--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about doing--

context.speaker: Edward R. Theobald III
context.text: --the State of Illinois.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --What if the -- is there anything unfair about this?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I think Justice Ginsburg wrote an opinion in -- I recall a Third Circuit case involving ERISA or some medical thing, and an issue came up that was quite relevant and nobody had really thought about it before or done much about it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And what she wrote, to my recollection, is: Well, we would like the advice of the lower court if they want to give it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And so we send it back for the Third Circuit to consider whether it's appropriate to reach the issue, and if it is appropriate to reach the issue, do so.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Can you tell me what the authority is for Congress to extinguish a right for a constitutional violation?

context.text: Meaning--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --assume that someone -- it was the question that Justice Alito asked you -- someone under of the age of 40, someone who's not covered by any statute, someone who's part of an employer under 20.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What would suggest to you in this statute that Congress intended to extinguish those people's rights?
Sure, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And I guess I think that that's -- that's pretty hard.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: --To be clear, Your Honor, I'm not saying the government has to let it go on.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: I'm saying the government has tools that are better drawn to it than eliminating even the peaceful, consensual conversation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But suppose -- and this is still Justice Kagan's question -- suppose it were a given, assume that those laws just did not work.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Could there then be consideration of a buffer zone?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, this is a hypothetical that I'm sure that you wouldn't accept in the context of your case, but suppose.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: --So, a few things.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: One, the reasons this Court gave in Hill for allowing the 8-foot no-approach zone was precisely that it only was about protecting unwilling listeners and it did not stop discussions with willing listeners.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: There are real people--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Counsel, do you accept that the record here shows that it did not work well in the sense that Justice Breyer--

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: --No, not at all.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --seems to use it?

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: So, as the size of the zone decreases, I think the -- the imposition on the speech rights is -- you know, gets less and less and better and better.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: And so the adequacy of the alternatives, for example, that may improve as you go.

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: It would still be a problem, I think, to have zones on the sidewalk where, even when no one's there, it's a criminal act to have a conversation.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Well, but that goes back to Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I mean, how is a law supposed to deal with -- with that, sort of the fluctuating conditions that may be at a particular clinic site?

context.speaker: Mark L Rienzi
context.text: That's -- that's precisely the point.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: Exactly right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's, I think, a little less than this courtroom.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: We measured this courtroom.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'd just like you to go back to Justice Scalia's question for one second.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I didn't hear the -- as he was saying that this case is not a protest case, it's simply about calm conversations.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And that is what I want to know if the evidence showed that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Isn't that more narrowly tailored?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, what this case involves, what these people want to do is to speak quietly and in a friendly manner, not in a hostile manner, because that would -- that would frustrate their purpose, with the people going into the clinic.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: But, again, experience showed that even individuals who wanted to engage in close, quiet, peaceful conversation were creating congestion around--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But you've cited some other evidence that suggests there were other people who were screaming, pushing and shouting, which sounds like, in his characterization, a protest case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the reason that Massachusetts found it difficult to write a statute that distinguishes one from the other is?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, let -- let me ask this question: Assume it to be true that an elderly lady who was quite successful and had meaningful communication with over 100 women going into the clinic, before this law, was unable to talk to even one after this law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Assume that's true.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Does that have any bearing on our analysis?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And does that have any bearing on Justice Breyer's question about whether or not a law can be written to protect that kind of activity but still to prevent obstruction and blocking?

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: I -- I think, Your Honor, that no one is guaranteed any specific form of communication.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: So, there is no guarantee, as a doctrinal matter, to close, quiet conversations.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: But, of course, that right is tempered by the -- the State's interest in making sure that the public sidewalks function as they should and that there is peace and good order.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: But I would give you an example, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: I'd -- I'd point you--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I still don't know where you're going to -- this -- this goes to Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You -- you cannot write an ordinance that says obstruction, intimidation, blocking is prohibited, and still allow the kind of conversation that I described earlier and that I want you to assume to be true for the -- for the purposes of this question.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: --Your Honor, we -- we couldn't here, obviously, because that wasn't the problem.

context.text: But in speech cases, when you address one problem, you have a duty to protect speech that's -- that's -- that's lawful.

context.speaker: Jennifer Grace Miller
context.text: --You do.

context.text: As long as your protection is narrowly tailored to your interest, you--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I -- I think what you have to say to this Court is that it's impossible to write a statute of the kind that we are discussing now, and this is Justice Breyer's question.

context.text: Is that--
